thread.section_title: www.telegraph.co.uk for the latest news from the UK and around the world.
thread.title: Jeremy Corbyn is now less popular than Michael Foot was at the same stage of his leadership
thread.title_full: Jeremy Corbyn is now less popular than Michael Foot was at the same stage of his leadership

author: Peter Dominiczak
title: Jeremy Corbyn is now less popular than Michael Foot was at the same stage of his leadership
text:
Jeremy Corbyn is now less popular than Michael Foot was at the same stage of his leadership Mr Corbyn is suffering poor approval ratings Credit: Danny Lawson /PA Peter Dominiczak , Political Editor  13am 
J eremy Corbyn is now more unpopular than former Labour leader Michael Foot was at the same stage of his leadership, polling has found. 
According to a survey by Ipsos Mori, Mr Corbyn now has a net rating of minus 38, lower than that of Mr Foot after he had been Labour leader for 17 months. 
In a further blow to Mr Corbyn it has emerged that Labour is facing an investigation to the Information Commissioner about breaches of data laws. 
It comes ahead of two crucial by-elections in Copeland and Stoke-on-Trent. Jeremy Corbyn pictured this week Credit: Paul Grover for the Telegraph 
M r Corbyn is facing allegations that Labour passed on the personal data of hundreds of thousands of Labour members to Momentum, the left-wing organisation that has campaigned on his behalf. 
In a letter the Information Commissioner in January said that the organisation is “currently being investigated by our enforcement department” and that it is expected to “conclude within two to three months”. 
Party sources believe that the data was passed to Momentum and then used to support Mr Corbyn’s leadership elections. 
The latest dire polling for Mr Corbyn puts him well behind Theresa May, the Prime Minister, in terms of personal popularity. Michael Foot had better ratings than Jeremy Corbyn at the same stage in his leadership Credit: Malcolm Gilson/Rex Features 
J ust 24 per cent of voters told the pollster they are satisfied with Mr Corbyn's performance , down two points on a month ago. 
Of those surveyed 62 per cent said that they are dissatisfied with Mr Corbyn, leaving him with a net rating of minus 38. 
Mr Foot led Labour to a catastrophic election defeat in 1983 and is considered to be the party’s worst ever leader. 
According to the poll for the Evening Standard newspaper, 53 per cent of adults said that they are satisfied with Mrs May’s performance, up eight points from January. 
Just over a third said that they are dissatisfied with the Prime Minister’s performance, giving her a net rating of plus 17. Theresa May is well above Jeremy Corbyn in the polls Credit: Darrin Zammit-Lupi/Reuters 
G ideon Skinner, head of political research at Ipsos MORI Social Research Institute, said: "The historical contrasts look good for Theresa May, but much more alarming for Jeremy Corbyn. 
"The Prime Minister is enjoying a better honeymoon at this stage then her two immediate predecessors, David Cameron and Gordon Brown. However, Corbyn’s ratings as a Labour opposition leader almost 18 months in are closer to Michael Foot’s." 
Labour insiders are increasingly pessimistic about losing the Copeland by-election, which was triggered by the resignation of backbencher Jamie Reed. 
The Prime Minister visited the constituency this week, amid growing confidence from the Conservatives that they stand a chance of winning the seat. 
Labour is facing allegations of “dirty tricks” after warning voters in the seat that a Tory victory will "cost mums their children". 
It follows another leaflet which this week claimed that cuts to maternity services at a local hospital will mean "mothers will die, babies will die, babies will be brain-damaged".
